== A penalty for violating minimum wage laws ==
=== Legal punishment === User should not lower their existing wage levels because of the minimum wage under the Labor Standards Act. The Minimum Wage Law provides the following for penalties for minimum wage violations.
Article 28 (penalty)
① A person who pays less than the minimum wage in violation of Article 6, paragraph 1 or 2, or who has lowered the previous wage for a minimum wage is sentenced to less than three years in prison or 20 million won. In this case, prison terms and fines may be serious (Article 28 of the Minimum Wage Act), as a result, for those who pay the minimum wage, as well as for those who are paid less than that.
Article 30 (billionable regualtion)
①If a representative of a corporation, an agent, a user, or any other employee commits a breach of Article 28 in respect of its business, he or she shall punish the person.
②The contractor shall carry out the joint responsibility in accordance with Article 6 paragraph 7. Even though the superintendent ordered him to carry out the joint responsibility, the contractor shall carry it out within the time limit of 6.
=== Minimum wage violation counseling and reporting === A case of minimum wage violations can be consulted at the Civil Affairs Center of the Ministry of Employment and Labor(1350). However, only counseling, and not reporting, is possible in 1350. If an employees wants to receive a report, they can report it on 'Civil Service 24' website that integrates and provides government services, complaints, policies and information. If the employee wishes to receive a petition for the relief of their rights due to the understudy of minimum wage, they may visit the local employment office of the plant or file a petition via the Internet.
=== Punishment status === In 2016, the Ministry of Employment and Labor presided over a total of 1,278 minimum wage violation cases. However, only 17 cases led to actual judicial proceeding, meaning less than 2 percent of cases received legal proceeding. About 98 percent of the cases were demarcated for 'corrective action'. Employers who violated the minimum wage law have been able to avoid charges or legal proceedings by taking corrective action. As a result of the lack of legal enforcement, according to the Bank of Korea's analysis report on the latest minimum wage trend and evaluation in 2016, the number of workers receiving less than the minimum wage continues to soar.
== Debate over consequences == Since the Minimum Wage Act was enacted in 1986, the minimum wage has been steadily rising. However, there are endless discussions over minimum wage laws and minimum wage increases.
The following table summarizes the pros and cons of minimum wage. {| class="wikitable" |+ !Arguments in favor of minimum wage laws !Arguments against minimum wage laws |- |Supporters of a minimum wage claim it has these effects:
*A minimum wage increase can lead to shorter business hours and shorter working hours, which can improve people's quality of life. * The minimum wage increase is close to the average monthly living cost of two to three households, calculated by the National Statistical Office. * According to the International Monetary Fund(IMF), the minimum wage is effective in raising productivity of workers, and the impact of the minimum wage increase on employment is somewhat exaggerated. * The minimum wage increase not only has a positive impact on stable living for the working families but also on boosting the national economy. *An upward wage adjustment improves worker's earning power and protects them from exploitation by employers. * |Opponents of a minimum wage claim it has these effects:
* With minimum wage, small merchants who are not able to pay high labor costs are burdened to hire employees. *Minimum wages cause fewer employees to hire and work less time. * The minimum wage is not a fundamental solution for low-paid workers to solve an excessive number of phenomena. * A minimum wage increase allows employees to employ highly productive workers. As a result, older people who are relatively less productive in labor are at greater risk of losing their jobs. * |}
== Opinions of journalists and scholars == Last year, the minimum wage committee decided to raise the minimum wage in 2018 by 16.4% from the previous year to 7,530 won. This is the largest increase (1060 won) in the past and the maximum increase in 16 years since 2001 (16.8 percent).<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.mk.co.kr/newsRead.php?no=205193&year=2018|title=다시 불붙는 최저임금 논쟁 속도조절vs1만원 공약 달성|last=Il-seon|first=Son|date=2018-03-30|work=Maeil Business News Korea|access-date=2018-06-10|language=ko|trans-title=Reignite minimum wage debate: Speed adjustment and a 10,000 won commitment}}</ref>
The effectiveness and feasibility of minimum wage increases are greatly debated topics. Both conservative newspapers and liberal pundits across South Korea were quick to denounce the new minimum wage measures. The [[The Chosun Ilbo|Chosun Ilbo]] reported on the day after the 2018 minimum wage increase was announced that [[Small and medium-sized enterprises|SMEs]] and small business owners were opposed to raising the minimum wage. They said, "The minimum wage increase is a measure that does not take into account the imminent reality of small and medium sized companies suffering from sluggish sales."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://biz.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2017/07/17/2017071700149.html|title=편의점·치킨업주 "차라리 내가 다른 가게 알바 뛰는 게 낫지"|last=Sung-jin|first=Chae|date=2017-07-17|work=조선일보|access-date=2018-06-10|language=ko|trans-title=Convenience store / chicken owner "I'd rather work part time at another store"}}</ref> The [[The Dong-a Ilbo|Dong-A Ilbo]] also criticized the government's minimum wage increase on the same day, reporting on the criticism of the 'Small Business Federation' and 'Korea Employers Federation'.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.donga.com/3/all/20170717/85383747/1|title=“알바월급 167만원, 사장은 186만원” 가게 접겠다는 업주들|last=Hyun-soo Kim, Ye-yoon Kim, Hye-ryeong Choi|first=|date=2017-07-17|work=동아일보|access-date=2018-06-10|language=ko|trans-title="Part-time job salary is 16.7 million won, the president is 1.86 million won", Owners who want to stop shop}}</ref> The [[JoongAng Ilbo]] reported on the support measures for small businesses and small businesses, which amount to 4 trillion won, and criticized it as "unpopular populism all over the world."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.joins.com/article/21762475|title=국민 세금으로 메꾸는 최저임금 7530원|last=Nam-hyeon|first=Ha|date=2017-07-17|work=중앙일보|access-date=2018-06-10|language=ko-KR|trans-title=Minimum wages and national taxes}}</ref> In addition, the [[The Dong-a Ilbo|Dong-A Ilbo]] reported on companies that decided to move the factory overseas with a minimum wage increase.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.donga.com/3/all/20170725/85507191/1|title=“최저임금 너무 올라”… 한국 떠나는 기업들|last=Se-jin Jung, Do-young Kwak|first=|date=2017-07-25|work=동아일보|access-date=2018-06-10|language=ko|trans-title="Minimum wage too high" ... Companies leaving Korea}}</ref> Ju Jin-hyung, who has served as general affairs policy committee chairman of [[Democratic Party of Korea|the Democratic Party]], pointed out through a [[Facebook]] post that the promise of the "minimum wage 10,000 won" promise and ambiguity, and lack of standard and impression standards.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/society/society_general/804396.html|title=최저임금 인상이 급격하다고? 찬반 논쟁 총정리|last=Da-hae|first=Park|date=2017-07-26|work=한겨레|access-date=2018-06-10|language=ko|trans-title=The minimum wage increase is rapid? Pros and cons}}</ref>
Many scholars, however, welcome and endorse the minimum wage increase. Jeong Tae-in, an economist and chief of the Karl Polanyi Center for Socio-Economic Studies, wrote a column in the progressive journalist [[Kyunghyang Shinmun]]. He argued in the column that the minimum wage increase does not affect employment: first, college students and young people who work part-time will reduce labor hours if the minimum wage goes up. Second, if the self-employed are concerned about the minimum wage increase, it is likely that it is due to the pressures of a franchise headquarters. Third, he argues reducing business hours to 8 hours a day would not reduce the sales of consumer goods by one-third, as some insist. If the minimum wage increase is the policy priority, shortening the operating hours will be a policy to compensate. Convenience stores, franchisees, and manufacturing subcontractors, in short, the government only have to assure the right to organize '[[Gapjil|Eul(을)]]'.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.khan.co.kr/kh_news/khan_art_view.html?code=990100&artid=201707241121001|title=[정태인의 경제시평]최저임금 타령|last=Tae-in|first=Jeong|date=|work=경향신문|access-date=2018-06-10|language=ko|trans-title=[Economy of Chung Tae-in] Minimum wage}}</ref>
Kim Chang-hwan, a professor of sociology at the [[University of Kansas]], USA, also objected to Ju Jin-hyung's argument. [http://sovidence.tistory.com/m/910 In his blog], he wrote, "The effect of the minimum hourly rate on the labor market is not established academically. The theory of economics suggests that if the minimum hourly rate is increased, the employment rate decreases. But the reality is that the minimum rate is cleaner than the theory." He also pointed out that there is a disagreement about whether it is bad for employment to decline by raising the minimum wage, and that high wages have the effect of promoting structural reforms and forcing productivity improvements. He said, "If businesses and self-employed people who can not afford the minimum wage are closed, the capital is absorbed into capital that can give more than the minimum wage, rather than being publicly decomposed." "In this case, the productivity of the economy as a whole is improved and structural upgrading is forced." Professor Kim also pointed out that the conservative press, which is promoting the 'minimization of employment by the minimum wage', is using the 'minimum wage increase' as a means of ideological struggle even though the new minimum wage is not applied yet. And he criticized Ju Jin-hyung, "If the minimum wage increase was a big problem, you should criticize the increase by 9% over 1989 and 12 times over 30 years. Until now, you have been quiet, but once the minimum wage raised the 16%, you can not criticize the minimum wage increase policy. If the Korean economy was ruined because the minimum wage was high, it would have been ruined."<ref name=":0" />

{{Refimprove|date=May 2010}} '''Modified starch''', also called '''starch [[derivative (chemistry)|derivatives]]''', are prepared by [[physical change|physically]], [[enzymatically]], or [[chemically]] treating native [[starch]] to change its properties.<ref name="Vaclavik">{{cite book | title = Essentials of food science | authors = "Vickie Vaclavik, Vickie A. Vaclavik, Elizabeth W. Christian" | edition = 3rd | publisher = Springer | year = 2007 | isbn = 978-0-387-69939-4 | page = 61}}</ref> Modified starches are used in practically all starch applications, such as in food products as a [[thickening agent]], [[Food additive#Categories|stabilizer]] or [[emulsifier]]; in [[pharmaceutical]]s as a [[Excipient#Disintegrants|disintegrant]]; or as binder in [[coated paper]]. They are also used in many other applications.<ref>Starch derivatization: fascinating and unique industrial opportunities, K. F. Gotlieb, A. Capelle, Wageningen Academic Publishers, 2005, {{ISBN|978-90-76998-60-2}}</ref>
Starches are modified to enhance their performance in different applications. Starches may be modified to increase their stability against excessive heat, acid, shear, time, cooling, or freezing; to change their [[texture (food)|texture]]; to decrease or increase their [[viscosity]]; to lengthen or shorten [[starch gelatinization|gelatinization]] time; or to increase their [[visco-stability]].
==Modification methods== [[File:Stärkeacetat.png|thumb|right|starch acetate]] [[File:Hydroxypropylstärke.png|thumb|right|hydroxypropylated starch]] [[File:Kationische Stärke.png|thumb|right|cationic starch]] [[File:Carboxymethylstärke.png|thumb|right|carboxymethylated starch]] Acid-treated starch ([[List of food additives, Codex Alimentarius|INS]] 1401),<ref name="GSFA">[http://www.codexalimentarius.net/gsfaonline/docs/CXS_192e.pdf Codex General Standard for Food Additives (GSFA) Online Database]</ref> also called thin boiling starch, is prepared by treating [[starch]] or starch granules with [[inorganic acid]]s, e.g. [[hydrochloric acid]] breaking down the starch molecule and thus reducing the viscosity.
Other treatments producing modified starch (with different INS and [[E-numbers]]) are: * [[dextrin]] (INS 1400),<ref name="GSFA" /> roasted starch with [[hydrochloric acid]] * alkaline-modified starch (INS 1402)<ref name="GSFA" /> with [[sodium hydroxide]] or [[potassium hydroxide]] * bleached starch (INS 1403)<ref name="GSFA" /> with [[hydrogen peroxide]] * oxidized starch (INS 1404, E1404)<ref name="GSFA" /> with [[sodium hypochlorite]], breaking down viscosity * enzyme-treated starch (INS 1405),<ref name="GSFA" /> [[maltodextrin]], [[cyclodextrin]] * monostarch phosphate (INS 1410, E1410) with [[phosphorous acid]] or the salts [[sodium phosphate]], [[potassium phosphate]], or [[sodium triphosphate]] to reduce [[retrogradation (starch)|retrogradation]] * [[Phosphated distarch phosphate|distarch phosphate]] (INS 1412, E1412) by esterification with for example [[sodium trimetaphosphate]], [[Cross-link|crosslinked]] starch modifying the [[rheology]], the texture * acetylated starch (INS 1420, E1420)<ref name="GSFA" /> [[esterification]] with [[acetic anhydride]] * hydroxypropylated starch (INS 1440, E1440), starch [[ether]], with [[propylene oxide]], increasing viscosity stability * [[hydroxyethyl starch]], with [[ethylene oxide]] * starch sodium octenyl succinate (OSA) starch (INS 1450, E1450) used as [[emulsifier]] adding [[hydrophobicity]] * starch aluminium octenyl Succinate (INS 1452, E1452) * [[Paper chemicals#Cationic starch|cationic starch]], adding positive [[electrical charge]] to starch * carboxymethylated starch with [[monochloroacetic acid]] adding negative charge and combined modifications such as *[[phosphated distarch phosphate]] (INS 1413, E1413) * acetylated distarch phosphate (INS 1414, E1414) * acetylated distarch adipate (INS 1422, E1422), * [[hydroxypropyl distarch phosphate]] (INS 1442, E1442), * acetylated oxidized starch (INS 1451, E1451).<ref name="GSFA" />
Modified starch may also be a cold-water-soluble, pregelatinized or instant starch which thickens and gels without heat, or a cook-up starch which must be cooked like regular starch. Drying methods to make starches cold-water-soluble are [[Food extrusion|extrusion]], [[drum drying]], [[spray drying]] or [[dextrin]]ization.
Other starch derivatives, the starch sugars, like [[glucose]], [[high fructose syrup]], [[glucose syrup]]s, [[maltodextrin]]s, starch degraded with [[amylase]] [[enzyme]] are mainly sold as liquid [[syrup]] to make a [[Sugar substitute|sweetener]].
==Examples of use and functionality of modified starch== Pre-gelatinized starch is used to thicken instant [[dessert]]s, allowing the food to thicken with the addition of cold water or milk. Similarly, cheese sauce granules (such as in [[Macaroni and Cheese]] or [[lasagna]]) or [[gravy]] granules may be thickened with boiling water without the product going lumpy. Commercial [[pizza topping]]s containing modified starch will thicken when heated in the oven, keeping them on top of the pizza, and then become runny when cooled.
A suitably modified starch is used as a [[fat substitute]] for low-fat versions of traditionally fatty foods, e.g. [[food industry|industrial]] milk-based desserts like [[yogurt]] or reduced-fat hard [[salami]] having about 1/3 the usual fat content. For the latter type of uses, it is an alternative to the product [[Olestra]].
Modified starch is added to frozen products to prevent them from dripping when defrosted. Modified starch, bonded with [[phosphate]], allows the starch to absorb more water and keeps the ingredients together. Modified starch acts as an emulsifier for [[French dressing]] by enveloping oil droplets and suspending them in the water. Acid-treated starch forms the shell of [[jelly bean]]s. Oxidized starch increases the stickiness of [[batter (cooking)|batter]].
Carboxymethylated starches are used as a [[wallpaper adhesive]], as [[textile printing]] thickener, as [[Tablet (pharmacy)|tablet]] [[Excipient|disintegrants]] and [[excipients]] in the pharmaceutical industry.
[[Cation]]ic starch is used as wet end [[sizing]] agent in [[paper machine|paper manufacturing]].
==Genetically modified starch== Modified starch should not be confused with [[genetically modified food|genetically modified]] starch, which refers to starch from [[genetically modified organism|genetically engineered plants]], such as those that have been genetically modified to produce novel fatty acids or carbohydrates which might not occur in the plant species being harvested. In the United States the term can also refer to foods that have been created by traditional cross-breeding rather than gene splicing.<ref>[http://www.fda.gov/newsevents/testimony/ucm115032.htm 1999 October 19, Statement of James H. Maryanski Ph.D, Biotechnology Coordinator, Center for Food Safety and Applied Nutrition, Food and Drug Administration].</ref> {{Citation needed|date=January 2011}}{{Dubious|date=January 2011}} In Europe the term "[[genetically modified organism|Genetically Modified Organism]]" is used solely where "the genetic material has been altered in a way that does not occur naturally through fertilisation and/or natural recombination".<ref>http://www.efsa.europa.eu/en/topics/topic/genetically-modified-organisms, European food Standards Agency, 24 April 2013</ref> The modification in "genetically modified" refers to the genetic engineering of the plant [[DNA]], whereas in the term "Modified Starch" seen on [[Mandatory labelling|mandatory]] [[Ingredients|ingredient]] [[Food labelling Regulations|labels]] it refers to the later processing or treatment of the starch or starch granules.
Genetically modified starch is of interest in the manufacture of [[biodegradable polymer]]s and noncellulose feedstock in the [[paper industry]], as well as the creation of new [[food additives]]. For example, researchers aim to alter the enzymes within living plants to create starches with desirable modified properties, and thus eliminate the need for enzymatic processing after starch is extracted from the plant.<ref>Zeeman et al. "Starch: Its Metabolism, Evolution, and Biotechnological Modification in Plants" in Annual Review of Plant Biology, 2010, http://www.annualreviews.org/doi/full/10.1146/annurev-arplant-042809-112301</ref>
==See also== *[[Acceptable daily intake]] *[[Retrogradation (starch)]] *[[Starch gelatinization]] *[[Resistant starch]]

S Huang, [[Ann-Christine Albertsson]]. 1995. *''Modified Starch'', Jenny Ridgwell, Ridgwell Press, 2001, {{ISBN|978-1-901151-07-7}}

'''Palladia, Inc.''' is a [[social services]] organization in [[New York City]], working with individuals and families challenged by [[addiction]], [[homelessness]], [[AIDS]], [[domestic violence]], [[poverty]] and [[Psychological trauma|trauma]]. Founded in 1970, Palladia was known as Project Return Foundation until 2002.<ref>{{cite news|title=Palladia - Healing and Housing|url=http://www.nynp.biz/current/archives/nynparchives/1003_October_2003_Edition.pdf|accessdate=12 June 2012|newspaper=New York Nonprofit Press|date=October 2003}}</ref> The organization began as a drug treatment facility and evolved to address the concerns of its clients, developing services such as [[domestic violence]] shelters, outpatient [[drug rehabilitation|drug treatment]] programs, [[parenting]] programs, AIDS outreach, alternatives to [[incarceration]], and transitional and permanent [[home|housing]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Purnick|first=Joyce|authorlink=Joyce Purnick|title=While Albany Fiddled, Many Got Burned|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/18/nyregion/metro-matters-while-albany-fiddled-many-got-burned.html|accessdate=12 June 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=18 July 1996}}</ref> Today Palladia serves over 1300 clients daily.<ref>{{cite web|title=Palladia website|url=http://www.palladiainc.org/Public/}}</ref>
Palladia has long focused on the particular needs of women in treatment, staging conferences,<ref>{{cite news|last=Klemesrud|first=Judy|title=Helping Troubled Women in an Era of Change|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1979/05/21/111027959.pdf|accessdate=12 June 2012|newspaper=New York Times|date=21 May 1979}}</ref> pioneering ways to bring services to hard-to-reach clients<ref>{{cite news|last=Martin|first=Douglas|title=Lessons in AIDS Come With a Curl|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/03/14/nyregion/about-new-york-lessons-in-aids-come-with-a-curl.html|accessdate=12 June 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=14 March 1992}}</ref> and developing programs that highlighted the connection between trauma and addiction.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Cadiz|first=Sharon|author2=Savage, Andrea|title=The Portal Project: A Layered Approach to Integrating Trauma into Alcohol and Other Drug Treatment for Women |journal=[[Alcoholism Treatment Quarterly]] |year=2004|volume=22|series=3/4|pages=121–139|url=http://www.nhchc.org/bibliograpy/portal-project-a-layered-approach-to-integrating-trauma-into-alcohol-and-other-drug-treatment-for-women/|accessdate=12 June 2012|doi=10.1300/j020v22n03_07|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Palladia also developed several specialized programs that fostered connections between parents undergoing treatment and their children.<ref>{{cite news|last=Weil|first=Jennifer|title=Helping Addict Moms - Bring-A-Kid Care Has High Success Rate|url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2002-12-08/local/18204104_1_pregnant-women-drug-treatment-substance-abuse-problems|accessdate=12 June 2012|newspaper=New York Daily News|date=8 December 2002}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Martin|first=Douglas|title=Becoming a True Father: A Rocky Road for Glenn|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/06/20/nyregion/about-new-york-becoming-a-true-father-a-rocky-road-for-glenn.html|accessdate=12 June 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=20 June 1992}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Kappstatter|first=Bob|title=Mom's 2nd Chance - Agency Helps Patch up Broken Families|url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2003-05-12/local/18219575_1_apartment-three-young-children-families|accessdate=12 June 2012|newspaper=New York Daily News|date=12 May 2003}}</ref>
==Social service programs== Palladia’s current programs include:<ref name="Palladia Website">{{cite web|title=Palladia Website|url=http://www.palladiainc.org/Public/default.aspx?Home}}</ref>
*Starhill and Ujima House, residential drug treatment centers *Aegis, an emergency domestic violence shelter *Athena House, a transitional domestic violence shelter *Willow, 126th Street and The Fane, emergency shelters *CTI - Bronx and CTI - Manhattan, outpatient drug treatment centers *Palladia Wellness Center, an outpatient mental health center *Esperanza, a transitional housing program *The Clinical Consultation Program, a partnership with NYC’s Administration for Children’s Services, in which Palladia provides clinical expertise for mental health, domestic violence and substance abuse issues that affect ACS families *HomeBase, a homelessness prevention program
==Supportive housing programs== Palladia uses [[real estate development]] to further its mission, and has eight permanent [[supportive housing]] buildings, which offer both housing and on-site social services to residents, who include homeless individuals and families, many affected by substance abuse, mental illness, medical disabilities and other challenges. Palladia’s supportive housing projects include the following buildings:<ref name="Palladia Website"/>
*Cedar Tremont, an 18 unit building for families, located in the Bronx<ref>{{cite news|last=Garcilazo|first=Miguel|title=A Home for Sunshine|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/boroughs/a-home-sunshine-article-1.726995|accessdate=12 June 2012|newspaper=New York Daily News|date=18 April 1996}}</ref> *Dreitzer House, a 38 unit building for families, located in Manhattan<ref>{{cite news|last=Kaufman|first=Leslie|title=City is Gambling on an Old Program to Cure Homelessness|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/07/19/nyregion/city-is-gambling-on-an-old-program-to-cure-homelessness.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|accessdate=12 June 2012|newspaper=New York Times|date=19 July 2004}}</ref> *Hill House, a 44 unit building for individuals, located in the Bronx<ref>{{cite news|last=Olmeda|first=Rafael|title=A Chance to Rebuild Lives|url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/1999-09-16/local/18120947_1_project-return-hill-house-opening-ceremony|accessdate=12 June 2012|date=16 Sep 1999}}</ref> *Jerome Court, a 41 unit building for individuals, located in the Bronx<ref>{{cite news|last=Olmeda|first=Rafael|title=Motel, Neighborhood Get Another Chance|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/boroughs/motel-neighborhood-chance-article-1.793244|accessdate=12 June 2012|newspaper=New York Daily News|date=2 April 1998}}</ref> *Stratford House, a 61 unit building for families, located in the Bronx<ref>{{cite news|last=Green|first=Penelope|title=A Former Addict Finds A Home for Her Family|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/11/09/realestate/habitats-soundview-the-bronx-a-former-addict-finds-a-home-for-her-family.html|accessdate=12 June 2012|newspaper=New York Times|date=9 Nov 2003}}</ref> *Chelsea Court, an 18 unit building for individuals, located in Manhattan<ref>{{cite news|last=Louie|first=Elaine|title=A Building and Its Residents, No Longer Down on Their Luck|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/05/08/garden/currents-housing-a-building-and-its-residents-no-longer-down-on-their-luck.html|accessdate=12 June 2012|newspaper=New York Times|date=8 May 2003}}</ref> *Flora Vista, a 20 unit building for individuals, located in Manhattan<ref>{{cite web|title=Supportive Housing Network - Tenant Profiles|url=http://shnny.org/learn-more/real-stories/crystal/|accessdate=13 June 2012}}</ref> *Fox Point, a 48 unit building for families and individuals, located in the Bronx<ref name="Economist - Big Green Apple">{{cite news|title=The Big Green Apple - Environmentally Sound Homes for the Poor Are a Model for Everyone Else|url=http://www.economist.com/node/15819127|accessdate=12 June 2012|newspaper=The Economist|date=31 March 2010}}</ref>
In addition, Palladia operates several “scattered site” supportive housing programs in the Bronx, Manhattan and Brooklyn.<ref name="Palladia Website"/>
==Awards and honors== *U.S. Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration’s Exemplary Program Award<ref name="findarticles.com">{{cite news|title=Palladia Earns Four Awards As the Nation Says 'Thank You'|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m3601/is_20_52/ai_n16033778/|accessdate=13 June 2012|newspaper=Real Estate Weekly|date=28 December 2005}}</ref> *Andrew Heiskell Community Renaissance Award<ref name="findarticles.com"/> *The HomeBase program, of which Palladia was a founding service provider, was a finalist for the finalist for [[Harvard University]]’s [[Kennedy School of Government]]’s Innovations in American Government Award<ref>{{cite web|title=HomeBase Homelessness Prevention Services|url=http://www.innovations.harvard.edu/awards.html?id=52611|accessdate=13 June 2012}}</ref> *Palladia's Cedar Tremont House won third place in the national MetLife awards for Excellence in Affordable Housing<ref name="MetLife Award - Project Return Foundation Cedar Tremont">{{cite web|title=Project Return Foundation: Cedar Tremont House|url=http://www.innovations.harvard.edu/showdoc.html?id=3364|publisher=Harvard Kennedy School|accessdate=26 October 2012}}</ref> *Palladia's Hill House won second place in the national MetLife awards for Excellence in Affordable Housing<ref name="Awards for Excellence in Affordable Housing">{{cite web|title=MetLife Awards for Excellence in Affordable Housing|url=http://www.practitionerresources.org/cache/documents/30970.pd|accessdate=26 October 2012}}</ref> *Palladia's Chelsea Court received the New York State Design Award of Merit, the New York Chapter Housing Design Award and the National Housing PIA Award from the [[American Institute of Architects]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Louise Braverman Architect|url=http://www.american-architects.com/en/louise.braverman/en/|accessdate=13 June 2012}}</ref> and was featured in ''Residential Architect'' magazine<ref>{{cite news|last=Maynard|first=Nigel|title=Chelsea Court, New York City|url=http://www.residentialarchitect.com/design/chelsea-court-new-york-city.aspx|accessdate=13 June 2012|newspaper=Residential Architect|date=May 2005}}</ref> *Chelsea Court was featured at the "Affordable Housing: Designing an American Asset" exhibition at the [[National Building Museum]]<ref>{{cite web|title=National Building Museum - Affordable Housing: Creating an American Asset|url=http://www.nbm.org/exhibitions-collections/exhibitions/affordable-housing.html|accessdate=13 June 2012}}</ref> in Washington D.C. and in the related book, ''Affordable Housing: Designing an American Asset''<ref>{{cite book|last=Schmitz|first=Adrienne|title=Affordable Housing: Creating an American Asset|year=2005|publisher=Urban Land Institute|isbn=978-0-87420-940-2}}</ref> *Chelsea Court was included in a profile of "New York's Best Affordable Housing"<ref name="Inside New York's Best Affordable Housing">{{cite news|last=Sheftell|first=Jason|title=Inside the Best of New York City’s Affordable Housing|url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2012-09-20/news/33982711_1_bronx-zoo-common-ground-homes|accessdate=22 October 2012|newspaper=New York Daily News|date=20 Sep 2012}}</ref> *Palladia's Aegis domestic violence shelter received a design makeover that was featured in ''Interior Design'' magazine,<ref>{{cite web|title=100 Big Ideas|url=http://www.interiordesign.net/projects/detail/1626-100-big-ideas/|work=Interior Design|accessdate=25 May 2014}}</ref> ''Real Estate Weekly'',<ref>{{cite web|title=Design Team Gives Young Victims a Bright New Facility|url=http://www.rew-online.com/2013/01/02/design-team-gives-young-victims-bright-new-facility/|work=Real Estate Weekly|accessdate=25 May 2014}}</ref> and ''eOculus''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Miller|first=Linda|title=The Gift of Good Design|url=http://main.aiany.org/eOCULUS/newsletter/in-the-news-6/|work=eOculus}}</ref> *Palladia's Fox Point is among the first [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED]] Gold<ref>{{cite web|title=LEED Certification Project List|url=http://www.usgbc.org/LEED/Project/CertifiedProjectList.aspx|accessdate=2 June 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081103030148/http://www.usgbc.org/LEED/Project/CertifiedProjectList.aspx|archivedate=3 November 2008|df=}}</ref> certified [[green buildings]]<ref name="Big Green Apple">{{cite news|title=Public Housing: The Big Green Apple|url=http://www.economist.com/node/15819127|accessdate=2 June 2012|newspaper=The Economist|date=March 31, 2010}}</ref> in the Bronx. The building also received certification from Green Communities<ref>{{cite web|title=Enterprise Community Partners website|url=http://www.enterprisecommunity.com/see-the-work-new-york|accessdate=2 June 2012}}</ref> and its design was profiled in ''Structure Magazine''<ref name=Structure>{{cite news|last=Pilla|first=Dominick|title=An Affordable and Sustainable Building Design in New York City|url=http://www.structuremag.org/article.aspx?articleID=1314|accessdate=2 June 2012|newspaper=Structure Magazine|date=September 2011}}</ref> and ''Green Building & Design'' magazine.<ref>{{cite web|last=van Loon|first=Benjamin|title=OCV Architects|url=http://gbdmagazine.com/2012/ocv-architects/|work=Green Building & Design|accessdate=25 May 2014}}</ref> *Fox Point's "Keeping Families Together" program was hailed as a successful alternative to foster care in a profile in ''City Limits'' magazine.<ref>{{cite web|last=Blustain|first=Rachel|title=Child Welfare Effort Avoids Taking Kids from Home by Giving Them One|url=http://www.citylimits.org/news/articles/5107/child-welfare-effort-avoids-taking-kids-from-home-by-giving-them#.U4Iea_ldV8E|work=City Limits|accessdate=25 May 2014}}</ref> *Fox Point was selected "Residence of the Year" by the Supportive Housing Network of New York.<ref name="SHNNY website">{{cite web|title=2012 Network Gala|url=http://shnny.org/events/2012-network-gala/|accessdate=26 October 2012}}</ref>

{{Use American English|date=October 2017}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2017}} '''People's Initiative''' (or "'''PI'''") is a common appellative in the [[Philippines]] that refers to either a mode for constitutional amendment provided by the 1987 Philippine Constitution or to the act of pushing an [[initiative]] (national or local) allowed by the Philippine Initiative and Referendum Act of 1987. The appellative also refers to the product of either of those initiatives. The provision in the 1987 [[Constitution of the Philippines]] allowing for a "people's initiative" as one of the modes for [[constitutional amendment]] has been called the "people's initiative clause." The other modes allowed by the Constitution involve a [[Constituent Assembly (Philippines)|Constituent Assembly]] (or "Con-Ass") or a [[Constitutional Convention (Philippines)|Constitutional Convention]] (or "Con-Con"), both of which also allow a total revision of the charter. The appellation (also known as "PI") also refers to the act—allowed by the law-given [[right]] of the [[Filipino people]]—of [[direct democracy|directly]] initiating [[statutes]] or calling for [[referenda]] on both the [[central government|national]] and the [[local government]] level. == Constitutional amendment initiatives == The process of [[Constitutional reform in the Philippines|amending the 1987 Constitution of the Philippines]] is popularly known to many Filipinos as [[Charter Change]]. Any proposed amendment or revision must be ratified by the majority of Filipinos in a plebiscite. Article XVII, Section 2 of the Constitution states:
Amendments to this Constitution may likewise be directly proposed by the people through initiative upon a petition of at least twelve per centum of the total number of registered voters, of which every legislative district must be represented by at least three per centum of the registered votes therein. No amendment under this section shall be authorized within five years following the ratification of this Constitution nor oftener than once every five years thereafter. The Congress shall provide for the implementation of the exercise of this right. {{Cite web|url = http://www.gov.ph/constitutions/the-1987-constitution-of-the-republic-of-the-philippines/the-1987-constitution-of-the-republic-of-the-philippines-article-xvii/|title = Article XVII of the 1987 Constitution of the Republic of the Philippines|date = |accessdate = 12 August 2014|website = gov.ph|publisher = The official Philippine government website|last = |first = }}
An [[enabling act|enabling law]] for this Article XVII, Section 2 Philippine Constitutional provision, called the Initiative and Referendum Act, was authored in 1987 by senators [[Raul Roco]] ([[Aksyon Demokratiko]]) and [[Neptali Gonzales]] ([[Liberal Party (Philippines)|Liberal Party]]) and was passed by the [[Eighth Congress of the Philippines]] in 1989. The law provides for the implementation of the exercise of the people's right to initiate a [[petition]] to amend the Constitution, with the Election Registrar of the [[Commission on Elections (Philippines)|Commission on Elections]] (Comelec) tasked under the law with the verification of the petition signatures' being by at least twelve per centum of the total number of registered voters in the state.{{Cite web|url = http://www.lawphil.net/statutes/repacts/ra1989/ra_6735_1989.html|title = AN ACT PROVIDING FOR A SYSTEM OF INITIATIVE AND REFERENDUM AND APPROPRIATING FUNDS THEREFOR|date = |accessdate = 30 September 2014|website = The LAWPHIL Project|publisher = [[Arellano Law Foundation]]|last = |first = }} ==Statute and referendum initiatives== The People's Initiative can also refer to the right of Filipinos to initiate statutes as well as call for referenda on both the national and local government level, a right given by the Initiative and Referendum Act of 1987, otherwise known as [[Republic Act#Notable Laws|Republic Act 6735]]. ===2014 People's Initiative Against Pork Barrel=== From late June to early August 2014, a People's Initiative Against Pork Barrel (PIAP) was repeatedly announced as up for launch in a forthcoming August 23 "people's congress" in [[Cebu City]]. The initiative, a multisectoral [[political alliance|alliance]]-driven proposition to [[criminalize]] [[pork barrel]] fund creation and spending, was led by various groups and individuals including Cebu Archbishop [[Jose S. Palma]], the broad #AbolishPorkMovement, the [[Catholic Church]]-backed Cebu Coalition Against the Pork Barrel System, the Church People's Alliance Against Pork Barrel, ePIRMA (Empowered People's Initiative and Reform Movement Alliance), the [[Makabayan]] Coalition (principally through [[Bayan Muna]] [[party-list]] representative [[Neri Colmenares]]), the Solidarity for Transformation, Youth Act Now, the Scrap Pork Network, and former [[Philippine Supreme Court]] Chief Justice [[Reynato Puno]].{{Cite news|url = http://bulatlat.com/main/2014/07/08/peoples-initiative-vs-pork-barrel-political-dynasty-gets-support-of-cbcp/|title = People's Initiative vs pork barrel, political dynasty gets support of CBCP|last = Salamat|first = Marya|date = 8 July 2014|work = Bulatlat.com|accessdate = 12 August 2014}}{{Cite news|url = http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/368021/news/nation/people-s-initiative-set-vs-pork-barrel-funds|title = People's initiative set vs. pork barrel funds|last = Arcangel|first = Xianne|date = 30 June 2014|work = [[GMA News Online]]|accessdate = 12 August 2014}}{{Cite news|url = http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/374086/news/nation/cbcp-president-supports-people-s-initiative-vs-pork-barrel|title = CBCP president supports people's initiative vs. pork barrel|last = Locsin|first = Joel|date = 9 August 2014|work = GMA News Online|accessdate = }} Retrieved August 12, 2014"[http://www.cbcpnews.com/cbcpnews/?p=39423 Bishops back people's initiative against pork barrel]". ''[[CBCP News]]''. [[Catholic Bishops' Conference of the Philippines]]. 9 August 2014. Retrieved August 12, 2014{{Cite news|url = http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/615868/5-things-you-need-to-know-about-peoples-initiative-against-pork-barrel|title = 5 things you need to know about People's Initiative Against Pork Barrel|last = Santos|first = Matikas|date = 1 July 2014|work =[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]] |accessdate = August 12, 2014}}{{Cite web|url = https://www.scribd.com/doc/236600451/People-s-Initiative-Petition-vs-Pork-Barrel-Updated-August-13-2014|title = People's Initiative Petition vs Pork Barrel (Updated August 13, 2014)|date = 13 August 2014|accessdate = 18 August 2014|website = [[Scribd]]|publisher = |last = Blogwatch.ph|first = }} The Cebu congress was immediately followed by a signature rally at [[Luneta Park]], on August 25, 2014.{{Cite news|url = http://www.bworldonline.com/content.php?section=Nation&title=thinner-crowd-at-anti-pork-rally-does-little-to-douse-fervor&id=93399|title = Thinner crowd at anti-pork rally does little to douse fervor|last = Monzon|first = Alden M.|date = August 25, 2014|work =Business World Online |accessdate = August 26, 2014}} The proposition was one of civil society's resulting reactions to the [[Priority Development Assistance Fund scam]] of 2013 and the [[Million People March]] and other protests that followed. An exploratory "people's congress" to draft an initiative on spending public funds was first convened by the ePIRMA at the [[Asian Institute of Management]] Conference Center on November 9, 2013, with Puno, Colmenares and ePIRMA's legal-team head Jose M. Roy III leading the conference that was attended by representatives from various groups coming from all over the country. ePIRMA and the "people's congress" alliance later scheduled its first draft to be completed by January 2014 while it was awaiting the [[Supreme Court of the Philippines|Supreme Court]]'s decision on prior petitions against both the [[Priority Development Assistance Fund]] (PDAF) and the "presidential pork" disbursements under [[Benigno Aquino III]]'s government's Disbursement Acceleration Program (DAP).{{Cite web|url = http://www.manilatimes.net/broad-alliance-to-hold-peoples-congress-today/51515/|title = Broad alliance to hold People's Congress today|date = November 8, 2013|accessdate = August 12, 2014|website = [[The Manila Times]]|publisher = |last =Villamente |first =Jing }}{{Cite news|url = http://www.mb.com.ph/e-p-i-r-m-a-peoples-congress/|title = E.P.I.R.M.A. People's Congress|last = Vicoy|first = Ali|date = November 9, 2013|work = [[Manila Bulletin]]|accessdate = August 26, 2014}}{{Cite web|url = http://manilastandardtoday.com/2013/11/10/-people-s-move-vs-pork-barrel-needs-p750m-/|title = People's move vs. pork barrel needs P750M|date = 10 November 2013|accessdate = August 12, 2014|website = [[Manila Standard Today]]|publisher = |last =Araja |first =Rio N. }}{{Cite web|url = http://1rgcruz.wordpress.com/2013/11/06/peoples-congress/|title = People's Congress|date = 6 November 2013|accessdate = August 12, 2014|website = @1RGCruz|publisher = R.G. Cruz|last = Cruz|first = R.G.}}{{Cite news|url = http://www.manilatimes.net/bicameral-meetings-another-pork-source/52347/|title = Bicameral meetings another pork source|last = Sy Egco|first = Joel M.|date = 11 November 2013|work = The Manila Times|accessdate = August 12, 2014}}{{Cite news|url = http://dokalternatibo.org/epirma-signature-campaign/|title = EPIRMA Signature Campaign Para Amyendahan Ang Saliganag Batas, Isinulong|last = |first = |date = 6 November 2014|work = Dok Alternatibo|accessdate = 12 August 2014}} Petitions against the PDAF were first filed with the Supreme Court by the [[Social Justice Society]] on August 28, 2013, by [[Greco Belgica]] et al. on September 3, 2013, and by Pedrito Nepomuceno on September 5, 2013. Petitions against the DAP were filed with the Supreme Court by nine separate groups of petitioners between October 7 and November 7, 2013. The petitioners included the [[Integrated Bar of the Philippines]], Bagong Alyansang Makabayan, [[GABRIELA Women's Party]], Bayan Muna, [[Ang Kapatiran]], and Belgica, among others. On November 19, 2013, the Supreme Court declared the PDAF unconstitutional;{{Cite news|url = http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2013/11/19/1258492/sc-declares-pdaf-unconstitutional|title = SC declares PDAF unconstitutional|last = Diola|first = Camille|date = November 19, 2013|work =[[The Philippine Star]] |accessdate = August 26, 2014}}{{Cite web|url = http://sc.judiciary.gov.ph/microsite/pdaf/|title = Main Decision: Priority Development Assistance Fund|date = November 20, 2013|accessdate = August 26, 2014|website = sc.judiciary.gov.ph|publisher = [[Supreme Court of the Philippines]]|last =Perlas-Bernabe |first =Estela M. }} a decision on the DAP came out seven and a half months later, on July 1, 2014, also declaring basic parts of the program as unconstitutional.{{Cite web|url = http://www.rappler.com/newsbreak/63267-understanding-supreme-court-ruling-dap|title = Understanding the SC ruling on the DAP|date = July 14–17, 2014|accessdate = August 26, 2014|website = Rappler.com|publisher =[[Rappler]] |last = Hofileña|first = Chay F.}}{{Cite web|url = http://www.rappler.com/business/features/63691-dap-supreme-court-say|title = DAP: What did the Supreme Court really say?|date = July 18–19, 2014|accessdate = August 26, 2014|website = Rappler.com|publisher =Rappler |last = Geronimo|first = Gerry}}{{Cite web|url = http://sc.judiciary.gov.ph/microsite/dap/|title = Main Decision: Disbursement Acceleration Program|date = July 2, 2014|accessdate = August 26, 2014|website = Sc.judiciary.gov.ph|publisher = Supreme Court of the Philippines|last =Bersamin |first =Lucas P. }} Under the PIAP's proposed Pork Barrel Abolition Act, all budgets submitted to any legislative body shall contain only itemized appropriations, except funds for relief and [[rescue operation]]s during [[calamities]] and funds for [[espionage|intelligence work]] and security. The proposed legislation also called for the abolition of the Presidential Social Fund, which has also been described as a form of pork barrel. Violators of this law were to be banned for life from holding public office.{{Cite news|url = http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/668396/pols-obstacles-in-bid-vs-pork-says-bishop|title = Pols obstacles in bid vs pork, says bishop|last = Mayol|first = Ador Vincent|date = January 28, 2015|work = Philippine Daily Inquirer|access-date = February 18, 2015|last2 = Matus|first2 = Carmel Loise}} On November 25, 2014, the ''[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]] ''reported that the Philippine Commission on Elections received the first 10,000 signatures from the initiative thrust in [[Quezon City]]. The signatures were from the city's first six districts, a first installment of the required 177,000 signatures from the entire city territory. Meanwhile, PIAP-[[Metro Manila]] coordinator Mark Lui Aquino said they had yet to submit to the Comelec the 50,000 to 100,000 signatures they had gathered in the metropolis. PIAP-Quezon City spokesperson Malou Turalde said, however, that Quezon City was not the first to submit to the Comelec gathered signatures for the initiative, adding that other legislative districts "just want to be quiet." Aquino also expressed fear that the "Comelec seems unready" and added that, based on his group's monitoring, the Comelec offices in the different cities and municipalities "do not know what to do with the signatures."{{Cite news|url = http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/652823/anti-pork-barrel-group-submits-10000-signatures-from-qc-for-peoples-initiative|title = Anti-pork barrel group submits 10,000 signatures from QC for people's initiative|last = Granali|first = Rima|date = November 25, 2014|work = Inquirer.net|access-date = December 12, 2014}} ==== Malacañang's resistance to the initiative ==== On September 4, 2014, Rep. Neri Colmenares announced that the ruling Liberal Party was trying to undermine the people's initiative against the pork barrel system. During his interpellation on the same day, at the [[16th Congress of the Philippines|Philippine Congress]] budget committee hearing on the 2015 budget for the Philippine [[Commission on Elections (Philippines)|Commission on Elections]], Colmenares noticed that the [[Malacañang Palace]] and its allies in Congress took out the budget that they had placed for a charter change (Cha-Cha) referendum they were planning to launch. Colmenares asked for the budget to be reinserted for the people's initiative plebiscite, but budget committee vice-chair Dakila Cua (Liberal Party, formerly [[Lakas Kampi CMD]]) said that Colmenares's motion should be made during the committee deliberations on the budget.{{Cite news|url = http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/09/04/14/palace-undermining-peoples-initiative-lawmaker|title = Palace undermining People's Initiative - lawmaker|last = Cruz|first = R.G.|date = September 4, 2014|work =[[ABS-CBN News and Current Affairs]] |accessdate = September 5, 2014}} A number of Liberal Party leaders and spokesmen earlier announced their wish to amend the Constitution to allow President [[Benigno Aquino III]] to run for re-election; as under the present Constitution the President cannot run again for the same office after his single six-year term.{{Cite news|url = http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/628668/issue-of-aquino-2nd-term-divides-liberal-party|title = Issue of Aquino 2nd term divides Liberal Party|last = Cabacungan|first = Gil C.|date = August 13, 2014|work =Philippine Daily Inquirer |accessdate = September 5, 2014}} Furthermore, groups against the pork barrel noted that the Aquino government had drafted a national budget for 2015 that still contained "pork" in the form of "special purpose funds," thus ignoring the earlier SC ruling on such funds' unconstitutionality as well as salient points in the PIAP. The groups further noted that this pork budget allocation had ballooned to 27 billion pesos, from the previous year's PHP25 billion pesos.The groups urged Congress to junk the budget.{{Cite news|url = http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/646082/congress-urged-to-junk-2015-budget-due-to-pro-dap-provisions|title = Congress urged to junk 2015 budget due to pro-DAP provisions|last = Gamil|first = Jaymee T.|date = October 21, 2014|work = Inquirer.net|accessdate = October 23, 2014}} On November 25, during the Senate plenary session tackling the said budget, Senator [[Miriam Defensor-Santiago]] raised the same points raised by the Makabayan group in the House of Representatives hearings, boosting the Makabayan position on the budget bill amendments.{{Cite news|url = http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/11/26/14/makabayan-finds-ally-miriam-pushes-forward-pi-vs-pork|title = Makabayan finds ally in Miriam, pushes forward with PI vs pork|last = Cruz|first = R.G.|date = November 26, 2014|work = ABS-CBNNews.com|access-date = December 3, 2014}} In January 2015, Palma reiterated the importance of the initiative, saying that although the Supreme Court had already declared the Priority Development Assistance Fund (PDAF) and the Disbursement Acceleration Program (DAP) as unconstitutional funds, members of Congress continued to enjoy discretionary funds under other forms. ==== Attack on anti-pork campaigner ==== On September 29, 2014, minutes after the anti-pork forum in [[Tagum City]], [[Davao del Norte]], which also launched the PIAP in the province, Dexter Ian Selebrado, 32, of the group Kilusang Magbubukid ng Pilipinas - Davao del Norte (Farmers' Movement of the Philippines - Davao del Norte) and one of the local campaigners against pork barrel funds, was attacked by motorcycle-riding gunmen.{{Cite news|url = http://www.rappler.com/nation/70566-anti-pork-barrel-slay-try|title = Anti-pork activist attacked by gunmen in Davao|last = Manlupig|first = Karlos|date = September 30, 2014|work = Rappler|accessdate = September 30, 2014}} As of October 1, the farmer-activist was still in critical condition.{{Cite news|url = http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/10/01/14/pnoy-urged-probe-shooting-anti-pork-leader|title = PNoy urged to probe shooting of anti-pork leader|last = |first = |date = October 1, 2014|work = ABS-CBNews.com|accessdate = October 7, 2014}} ==== Politicians' resistance to the initiative ==== In his January 2015 [[news conference|conference with the press]], Palma lamented the intervention of [[politicians]] in the turnout of citizens at the signature centers in his [[parishes]]. Apart from a lack of knowledge about the pork barrel, Palma claimed that a low turnout was also a result of there being families who had children enrolled in schools under politicians' pork-funded [[scholarships]] whose relatives then refused to sign the proposition. Turnout results in other [[dioceses]] were also not good, he said. He promised, however, that the Church would not be disheartened and cited the strong support of people in such dioceses as [[Calbayog City]]. ==== The initiative and the pork barrel issue by 2016 ==== In his blog of July 4, 2016, direct democracy advocate Jojo Soria de Veyra, a member of ePIRMA, confessed that after the initiative's launch "the signature gathering was mostly left to certain parishes of the more organized Catholic Church, the primary backing of the Cebu Coalition. Sporadic rallies of support were organized by the Makabayan group and provincial groups. Other members of ePIRMA were seen to have moved on to various other national concerns. [[Manny SD Lopez]]—ePIRMA's leading convenor and most active campaigner on the road—would also busy himself with organizing the Christian Peace Alliance, one of the groups advocating for a drastic review of some provisions of the then-in-its-final-thrust [[Bangsamoro Basic Law]]. Lopez would also form the EdlSA 2.22.15 Coalition, a group that called for President Benigno Aquino III's resignation after the [[Mamasapano clash|Mamasapano mishap]]. I submit that in this latter period I was not privy anymore to how the signature-gathering for the initiative on the pork barrel was progressing. I did hear of some pockets of resistance to the initiative, as well as the Comelec's seeming lack of enthusiasm towards verifying the signatures, but that's about it. . . . Then came the various noises leading to the [[Philippine general election, 2016|2016 general election]], within which news concerning the initiative's progress were nowhere anymore to be found on Google." De Veyra, also a convenor of a Facebook group called Forum for Direct Democracy, then proceeded in his blog to propose amendments to the Initiative and Referendum Act that would make the law easier for the people to use as well as obligate Comelec to do its part in the initiative process within a limited time period.{{Cite web|url=http://jojosoriadeveyra.blogspot.com/2016/07/my-amendment-proposals-to-initiative.html|title=Social / -Isms: My amendment proposals re the Initiative and Referendum Act (RA 6735)|last=Veyra|first=Jojo Soria De|date=2016-07-04|website=Social / -Isms|access-date=2016-07-09}} Meanwhile, on August 31, Senator [[Panfilo Lacson]] told the media that "the ₱3.35-trillion proposed budget presented by Malacañang [under the newly-elected [[Presidency of Rodrigo Duterte|Duterte administration]]] to the Senate for congressional approval is laden with 'pork' and violated the Supreme Court rulings on the Priority Development Assistance Fund and Disbursement Acceleration Program."{{Cite web|url=http://thestandard.com.ph/news/-main-stories/top-stories/214832/lacson-2017-budget-laden-with-pork-barrel.html|title=Lacson: 2017 budget laden with pork barrel|access-date=2016-09-07}} ==See also== * [[Constitutional reform in the Philippines]] * [[Direct democracy]] == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.chanrobles.com/philsupremelaw2.html#.V3n4JR1S02w The 1987 Constitution Of The Republic Of The Philippines] * [http://www.signupvspork.org/ The PIAP website] [[Category:Philippine law]] [[Category:Referendums in the Philippines]] [[Category:Politics of the Philippines]] [[Category:Initiatives]] [[Category:Referendums]] [[Category:Direct democracy]] [[Category:Democracy]] [[Category:Right to petition]] [[Category:Sources of law]]

The '''Section carrément anti-[[Jean-Marie Le Pen|Le Pen]]''' (SCALP; "Absolutely anti-Le Pen group") is a French [[Anti-fascism|anti-fascist]] and [[libertarian socialism|anarchist]] group,<ref name="Serge Cosseron">Serge Cosseron, ''[[:fr:Dictionnaire de l'extreme gauche]]'', Paris, Larousse, 2007, p. 77-79.</ref> formed in [[Toulouse]] in 1984 as a manifestation of the [[Autonomism|autonomist movement]].<ref>[http://kinoks.org/spip.php?article115 « Le jingle sonore réalisé par le SCALP pour la manif du 5 mars 1985 »]</ref>
==Background== The success of a group by the name of SCALP (Société contre les amis de Le Pen - Society against the friends of [[Jean-Marie Le Pen|Le Pen]]) in attracting media attention at a rally in Toulouse on June 6, 1984 led to the creation of numerous other groups sharing the same acronym in different cities around France. This first wave of SCALPs, developing alongside the [[alternative rock]] movement, disbanded in the early 1980s. An attempt to unite the different groups under a proposed National Anti-Fascist Representative Committee (''Coordination nationale antifasciste,'' CNAF) never took off, the Paris section of SCALP splintering in 1990.
==History== After one or two years of dormancy, elements of the original Paris SCALP who had been running the magazine ''REFLEXes'' (so named because most contributors were former students of [[Paris X University Nanterre|Paris X University]]) revived SCALP, using the acronym and the mythos surrounding it to attract the interest of young recruits. At the same time, the new SCALP distanced itself from the [[autonomist movement]] (elements of the original SCALP loyal to this movement dedicated themselves to other organizations and projects such as Karoshi and the CNT-AIT), opting to align itself more closely with traditional libertarian groups. Some members later left to join the [[Confédération nationale du travail|National Confederation of Labour]].
In 1992, the new SCALP organized itself into a national network called No Pasaran Network - a federation of the different local SCALP groups. The Paris group became known as SCALP-REFLEX ('''''R'''éseau d''''é'''tudes sur le '''f'''ascisme et de '''l'''utte contre l''''e'''xtrême droite et la '''x'''énophobie'' - Network for the study of [[fascism]] and the fight against the [[far right]] and [[xenophobia]]). The radical measures taken by the network during their [[Direct action|actions]] resulted in damage to premises and public property.{{Citation needed|date=April 2008}}
In 2004, more individuals quit the group, later going on to found the Libertarian and Social Offensive (''Offensive libertaire et sociale,'' OLS).
In 2006 SCALP-REFLEX participated in demonstrations and university ''assemblées générales''. They were involved in the occupation of the [[École des hautes études en sciences sociales|School for Advanced Studies in the Social Sciences]] (''École des hautes études en sciences sociales'', EHESS). Activists from the group clashed with those of the far right at a rally outside the [[Sorbonne]] on March 14, 2006.
On May 9, 2007 the group, along with other libertarian and student organisations ([[Alternative Libertaire]], [[Solidaires Unitaires Démocratiques|Union syndicale Solidaires]], [[Confédération nationale du travail|CNT]]), called for a counter-demonstration to be held to physically oppose a demonstration by the far right and to "show them they don't own the street." Fearing a police crackdown, the organisers - with the exception of SCALP - called for the counter-demonstration to be canceled. Several activists who attended the rally were arrested.{{Citation needed|date=April 2008}}
==Current status==
If current estimates of the group's strength as between 400 and 500 members are correct, more than 6000 people may have passed through its ranks since its founding{{Citation needed|date=April 2008}}.
Pornographic actress [[Ovidie]] is a former member of SCALP{{Citation needed|date=April 2008}}.
==Publications==
''No Pasaran'', the monthly publication of the network, is circulated in libraries and sectional offices. Numerous pamphlets on the [[far right]] have also been authored by the group.
In 2005 SCALP published ''Comme un indien Métropolitain'' (Like a French Indian), which deals with the history of the movement between 1984 and 1992.
==See also== {{Portal|Anarchism}} *[[Anti-fascism]] *[[Anarchist communism]] *[[Far left]] *[[Revolutionary movements]]

{{About|conspiracy theories|opposition cabinets in parliamentary systems|Shadow Cabinet}} {{More footnotes|date=May 2011}} The '''shadow government''' ('''cryptocracy''', '''secret government''', or '''invisible government''') is a family of [[conspiracy theories]] based on the notion that real and actual political power resides not with [[representative democracy|publicly elected representatives]] but with private individuals who are exercising power behind the scenes, beyond the scrutiny of democratic [[Institution|institution]]s. According to this belief, the official elected government is subservient to the shadow government which is the true executive power. Some of the groups proposed by these theories as constituting the shadow government include [[central bank]]s; [[Masonic conspiracy theories|Freemasons]], [[Intelligence agency|intelligence agencies]]; [[think tanks]]; [[The Protocols of the Elders of Zion|organized Jewry]]; [[Holy See|the Vatican]]; [[secret societies]]; [[Jesuit conspiracy theories|Jesuits]]; [[Corporatocracy|moneyed interests]]; [[New World Order (conspiracy theory)|globalist elites and supranational organizations]] who seek to manipulate policy in their own interest or in order to serve a larger agenda that is hidden from the general public. ==History== Literature on the subject postulates the existence of a secret government which is the true power behind the apparent government. Examples of such literature include works by [[Dan Smoot]], [[William Guy Carr]], [[Jim Marrs]], [[Carroll Quigley]], [[Gary Allen]], [[Alex Jones (radio host)|Alex Jones]], [[Des Griffin]], [[G. Edward Griffin]], [[David Icke]], and [[Michael A. Hoffman II]]. Some of these authors believe members of the secret government may represent or be agents for groups such as the [[Council on Foreign Relations]], the [[Royal Institute for International Affairs]], the [[Trilateral Commission]], the [[Bilderberg Group]], [[CIA]] and [[MI6]] in co-operation with international banks and financial institutions such as the [[World Bank]] and the [[Bank for International Settlements]].Chatham House ([[Royal Institute for International Affairs|RIIA]]) and the [[Council on Foreign Relations|CFR]], its US sister organization, are the focus of Quigley's ''The Anglo-American Establishment''.The CFR as a central institution of the secret government of the United States is the focus of James Perloff's book ''The Shadows of Power''Jim Marrs cites all the institutions listed in this paragraph in his study ''Rule By Secrecy'', published by Harper Collins. Also popularizing the idea was the hit US television show, ''[[The X-Files]]''. [[Milton William Cooper]] claimed that the shadow government was in cooperation with [[Extraterrestrials|extraterrestrial aliens]]. His 1991 book ''Behold A Pale Horse'',{{cite book|author=Michael Barkun|title=A Culture of Conspiracy: Apocalyptic Visions in Contemporary America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LiwjVsNBw-cC&pg=PA60|accessdate=5 January 2012|date=4 May 2006|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-24812-0|pages=60–}}{{cite book|last=Carroll|first=Robert Todd|title=The Skeptic's Dictionary: A Collection of Strange Beliefs, Amusing Deceptions, and Dangerous Delusions|year=2003|publisher=John Wiley & Sons, Inc.|location=Hoboken, New Jersey|isbn=9781118045633|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6FPqDFx40vYC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|authorlink=Robert Todd Carroll|accessdate=January 17, 2013|page=175|chapter=Illuminati|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=6FPqDFx40vYC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA175#v=onepage&q&f=false}} influential among "UFO and militia circles",{{cite book|last=Nattrass|first=Nicoli|title=The AIDS Conspiracy: Science Fights Back|year=2012|publisher=Columbia University Press|location=New York|isbn=9780231149129|pages=4, 23–27|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TehyoBCpVHYC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|authorlink=Nicoli Nattrass|accessdate=January 17, 2013}} describes "the doings of the secret world government" and "a variety of other covert activities associated with the Illuminati's declaration of war upon the people of America".{{cite book|last=Gilroy|first=Paul|title=Against Race: Imagining Political Culture Beyond the Color Line|year=2000|publisher=Harvard University Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=9780674000964|pages=352–353|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wWpt-Js7JPEC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|authorlink=Paul Gilroy|accessdate=January 17, 2013|chapter=Planetary Humanism|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=wWpt-Js7JPEC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA352#v=onepage&q&f=false}} Cooper claimed to have seen secret documents while in the Navy describing governmental dealings with aliens. Cooper linked the [[Illuminati]] with his beliefs that extraterrestrials were secretly involved with the US government, but later retracted these claims. He accused [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] of negotiating a treaty with extraterrestrials in 1954, then establishing an inner circle of Illuminati to manage relations with them and keep their presence a secret from the general public. Cooper believed that aliens "manipulated and/or ruled the human race through various secret societies, religions, magic, witchcraft, and the occult", and that even the Illuminati were unknowingly being manipulated by them. Cooper described the [[Illuminati]] as a secret international organization, controlled by the [[Bilderberg Group]], that conspired with the [[Knights of Columbus]], [[Freemasonry|Masons]], [[Skull and Bones]], and other organizations. Its ultimate goal, he said, was the establishment of a [[New World Order (conspiracy theory)|New World Order]]. According to Cooper the Illuminati conspirators not only invented alien threats for their own gain, but actively conspired with extraterrestrials to take over the world. Cooper believed that [[James Forrestal]]'s fatal fall from a window on the sixteenth floor of [[Walter Reed National Military Medical Center|Bethesda Hospital]] was connected to the alleged secret committee [[Majestic-12]], and that [[JASON (advisory group)|JASON advisory group]] scientists reported to an elite group of [[Trilateral Commission]] and [[Council on Foreign Relations]] executive committee members who were high-ranking members of the Illuminati.{{cite book|author=Richard Allen Landes|title=Heaven on Earth: The Varieties of the Millennial Experience|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9TulaFe5FTYC&pg=PA418|accessdate=4 January 2012|date=4 August 2011|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-975359-8|pages=418–}}{{cite book|author=Arthur Goldwag|title=Cults, Conspiracies, and Secret Societies: The Straight Scoop on Freemasons, the Illuminati, Skull and Bones, Black Helicopters, the New World Order, and Many, Many More|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DDbM5GeMgXIC|accessdate=4 January 2012|date=11 August 2009|publisher=Random House Digital, Inc.|isbn=978-0-307-39067-7}} == Quotations ==
"The real menace of our Republic is the invisible government, which like a giant octopus sprawls its slimy legs over our cities, states and nation."—[[John Francis Hylan|John Hylan]], Mayor of [[New York City]], 1922
"Behind the ostensible government sits enthroned an invisible government owing no allegiance and acknowledging no responsibility to the people."—From the Platform of President [[Theodore Roosevelt]]'s Progressive ("[[Progressive Party (United States, 1912)|Bull Moose]]") Party.{{Cite book|url=http://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/3335|title=Theodore Roosevelt: An Autobiography|last=Roosevelt|first=Theodore|publisher=The Floating Press|year=2014|isbn=978-1-77653-337-4|location=Auckland, New Zealand|pages=|via=}}
"The conscious and intelligent manipulation of the organized habits and opinions of the masses is an important element in democratic society. Those who manipulate this unseen mechanism of society constitute an invisible government which is the true ruling power of our country. We are governed, our minds are molded, our tastes formed, our ideas suggested, largely by men we have never heard of."—[[Edward Bernays]], the "father of [[public relations]]", writing in his influential 1928 book ''[[Propaganda_(book)|Propaganda]]''. Edward Bernays. Propaganda. (Routledge, 1928), 9.
“But quite frankly there is an outside source which we refer to as the '[[Deep state in the United States|deep state]]' or the 'shadow government'. There is a lot of influence by people which are actually more powerful than our government itself, our president,”. "— [[Ron Paul]], former [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]], November 2016 (following [[Donald Trump]] presidential election win).{{cite news|title=Trump should resist neocon & shadow gov’t influence to justify people’s hopes – Ron Paul to RT|url=https://www.rt.com/usa/366404-trump-ron-paul-crosstalk/|accessdate=11 November 2016|work=[[RT (TV network)]]|language=en-EN|date=16 January 2017}}

[[Brooklyn]] (2009–2014) | distribution = | keypeople = | publications = [[Book]]s | topics = | genre = | imprints = | revenue = | owner = Worker-owned and -operated collective | numemployees = | url = www.southendpress.org (dead link) }} '''South End Press''' was a [[non-profit]] [[book publisher]] run on a model of [[participatory economics]].{{Citation needed|date=April 2015}} It was founded in 1977 by [[Michael Albert]],{{r|mase}} [[Lydia Sargent]], [[Juliet Schor]],{{r|ias}} among others, in [[Boston]]'s [[South End, Boston|South End]]. It published books written by [[political activism|political activists]], notably [[Arundhati Roy]], [[Noam Chomsky]], [[bell hooks]], [[Winona LaDuke]], [[Manning Marable]], [[Ward Churchill]], [[Cherríe Moraga]], [[Andrea Smith (academic)|Andrea Smith]], [[Howard Zinn]], [[Jeremy Brecher]] and Scott Tucker. South End Press closed in 2014. ==History== South End Press was founded in 1977 by [[Michael Albert]],{{r|mase}} [[Lydia Sargent]], John Schall, Pat Walker, [[Juliet Schor]], Mary Lea, Joe Bowring, and Dave Millikan, among others. It was based in [[Boston]]'s [[South End, Boston|South End]] and run as a [[egalitarian]] [[collective]] with decision-making equally shared. The publisher experienced financial difficulties in the [[financial crisis of 2007–08]], with sales dropping by 12.8% in 2008. In 2009, South End Press moved to a new office in [[Brooklyn]], [[New York City|New York]], partnering with [[Medgar Evers College]] of the [[City University of New York]]. A fundraising campaign was run in 2012 to help ease its financial situation. South End Press closed in July 2014. Howard Zinn and an anonymous author had reportedly not received royalties for several years. ==Legacy== Some of South End Press's catalogue has been republished including work by Howard Zinn, Noam Chomsky, Dana Frank and Vanessa Tait (on [[Haymarket Books]]), Jeremy Brecher (on [[PM Press]]), and Eli Clare, Andrea Smith, Frank Wilderson and Dean Spade (on [[Duke University Press]]), and [[Vandana Shiva]] (on [[North Atlantic Books]]).{{Cite web|url=https://www.northatlanticbooks.com/blog/letter-from-the-publisher-vandana-shiva/|title=Letter from the Publisher: Vandana Shiva - North Atlantic Books|date=2015-08-21|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-07}} In 2014, commenting on the demise of the publisher, ''[[Monthly Review]]'' said it was ''"... an important and vital part of the overall left movement ... "''.{{cite web|url=https://monthlyreview.org/2014/10/01/mr-066-05-2014-09_0/|title=October 2014 (Volume 66, Number 5) - The Editors - Monthly Review|author=|date=1 October 2014|website=monthlyreview.org|accessdate=20 April 2018}} ==Related projects== The founders of South End Press have also been involved with two ongoing political media projects, 'Speak Out' and '[[Z Magazine]]'.
